options.option_text: YES

The sender task will be blocked permanently

questions.question_text_1: Consider a finite state machine (FSM) controlling a motor speed system with a single button. The states and events are defined as follows: States: 1. STATE_STOPPED – Motor is off. 2. STATE_SLOW – Motor runs at slow speed. 3. STATE_FAST – Motor runs at fast speed. 4. STATE_OVERSPEED – Motor runs at an unsafe speed. Events: 1. EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS – Button is pressed. 2. EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT – A sensor detects overspeed.
questions.question_text_2: Consider a finite state machine (FSM) controlling a motor speed system with a single button. The states and events are defined as follows: States: 1. STATE_STOPPED – Motor is off. 2. STATE_SLOW – Motor runs at slow speed. 3. STATE_FAST – Motor runs at fast speed. 4. STATE_OVERSPEED – Motor runs at an unsafe speed. Events: 1. EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS – Button is pressed. 2. EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT – A sensor detects overspeed. If the initial state is STATE_SLOW, what will be the next state after one EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS and one EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT event?
question_texts: Consider a finite state machine (FSM) controlling a motor speed system with a single button. The states and events are defined as follows: States: 1. STATE_STOPPED – Motor is off. 2. STATE_SLOW – Motor runs at slow speed. 3. STATE_FAST – Motor runs at fast speed. 4. STATE_OVERSPEED – Motor runs at an unsafe speed. Events: 1. EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS – Button is pressed. 2. EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT – A sensor detects overspeed.

Consider a finite state machine (FSM) controlling a motor speed system with a single button. The states and events are defined as follows: States: 1. STATE_STOPPED – Motor is off. 2. STATE_SLOW – Motor runs at slow speed. 3. STATE_FAST – Motor runs at fast speed. 4. STATE_OVERSPEED – Motor runs at an unsafe speed. Events: 1. EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS – Button is pressed. 2. EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT – A sensor detects overspeed. If the initial state is STATE_SLOW, what will be the next state after one EVENT_BUTTON_PRESS and one EVENT_SENSOR_ALERT event?

options.option_text: STATE_STOPPED
STATE_FAST
STATE_OVERSPEED
STATE_SLOW

questions.question_text_1: What is the main issue caused by priority inversion in an RTOS?
question_texts: What is the main issue caused by priority inversion in an RTOS?

options.option_text: High-priority tasks being blocked by low-priority tasks holding a sharedresource
Low-priority tasks consuming all CPU time
Tasks executing in an unpredictable order
RTOS scheduler failing to schedule tasks correctly

questions.question_text_1: What is the main advantage of using timers in an RTOS?
question_texts: What is the main advantage of using timers in an RTOS?

options.option_text: Allows periodic execution of tasks without busy-waiting
Increases CPU utilization by running tasks continuously
Prevents task preemption in a multitasking environment
Eliminates the need for task scheduling
Blocks the task indefinitely
Suspends the task without deleting its resources
Removes the task from the scheduler and frees allocated resources
Lowers the priority of the task instead of deleting it

questions.question_text_1: In which situation should an interrupt be used instead of polling?
question_texts: In which situation should an interrupt be used instead of polling?

options.option_text: Monitoring a push button for user input
Checking a sensor value every 5 seconds
Updating system logs every minute
Sending periodic status updates over UART

questions.question_text_1: Which is considered the best practice for optimizing memory usage in an embedded system?
question_texts: Which is considered the best practice for optimizing memory usage in an embedded system?

options.option_text: Using dynamic memory allocation extensively
Minimizing the use of global variables and using stack-based allocation
Keeping all variables in global memory for quick access
Increasing the heap size to accommodate more dynamic allocations

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of unit testing in software development?
question_texts: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of unit testing in software development?

options.option_text: Unit testing ensures that all the components of a software system worktogether as intended.
Unit testing involves testing the entire software system to ensure it meets theend user's requirements.
Unit testing is a method used to test hardware components in an embeddedsystem.
Unit testing focuses on verifying the correct behavior of individual units ofcode, such as functions, in isolation from the rest of the system.

questions.question_text_1: What are the final values of AX, BX, and CX registers after executing the following assembly code. MOV AX, 60 MOV BX, 95 ADD AX, BX MOV CX, AX MOV DX, 40 SUB BX, DX
question_texts: What are the final values of AX, BX, and CX registers after executing the following assembly code. MOV AX, 60 MOV BX, 95 ADD AX, BX MOV CX, AX MOV DX, 40 SUB BX, DX

questions.question_text_1: A microcontroller is running a main program that continuously updates a sensor value. An external interrupt is triggered to handle a button press. Why must the ISR save and restore the context before returning to the main program?
question_texts: A microcontroller is running a main program that continuously updates a sensor value. An external interrupt is triggered to handle a button press. Why must the ISR save and restore the context before returning to the main program?

options.option_text: To prevent the button press from being registered multiple times
To ensure the sensor update process resumes correctly after the ISR execution
To reduce the power consumption of the microcontroller
To allow the ISR to execute faster without delays

questions.question_text_1: You are designing a system with a microcontroller that needs to communicate with multiple temperature sensors. Which communication protocol would be more suitable for this scenario and why?
question_texts: You are designing a system with a microcontroller that needs to communicate with multiple temperature sensors. Which communication protocol would be more suitable for this scenario and why?

options.option_text: I2C, because it requires only two wires to communicate with multiple sensors
SPI, because it provides faster data transfer and supports full-duplexcommunication
I2C, because it allows multiple sensors to be connected without needingseparate Chip Select lines
SPI, because it can only communicate with one sensor at a time

questions.question_text_1: A CPU has 256KB of SRAM connected to it, starting at address 0x00400000. What is the address of the last byte in the SRAM?
question_texts: A CPU has 256KB of SRAM connected to it, starting at address 0x00400000. What is the address of the last byte in the SRAM?

options.option_text: 0x0043FFFF
0x004FFFFF
0x0043FFFE

questions.question_text_1: You are designing an embedded system that stores sensor readings in an array. The sensor values range from 0 to 100. To optimize memory usage, which data type should you choose for storing these values?
question_texts: You are designing an embedded system that stores sensor readings in an array. The sensor values range from 0 to 100. To optimize memory usage, which data type should you choose for storing these values?

options.option_text: int
unsigned int
uint16_t
uint8_t
0xD0
0x1A

questions.question_text_1: A microcontroller needs to play a high-quality audio file by sending data to an I2S-based audio codec. The audio buffer in memory holds 16-bit PCM data at a sampling rate of 44.1 kHz. What is the best method to ensure smooth audio playback without CPU overload?
question_texts: A microcontroller needs to play a high-quality audio file by sending data to an I2S-based audio codec. The audio buffer in memory holds 16-bit PCM data at a sampling rate of 44.1 kHz. What is the best method to ensure smooth audio playback without CPU overload?

options.option_text: The CPU loads and sends each audio sample to the I2S peripheral manually.
Use an interrupt to transfer data each time the I2S buffer is empty.
Set up DMA to transfer audio data from memory to the I2S peripheralautomatically.
Use a while loop to continuously send data to the I2S interface.

questions.question_text_1:
You are developing an image processing application that applies filters to high-resolution images. After releasing the first version, you notice that the application takes a long time to process multiple images. You use a profiling tool and discover that the main bottleneck is the time spent loading and saving images to disk. 
What is the most effective optimization to improve the application's performance?
question_texts:
You are developing an image processing application that applies filters to high-resolution images. After releasing the first version, you notice that the application takes a long time to process multiple images. You use a profiling tool and discover that the main bottleneck is the time spent loading and saving images to disk. 
What is the most effective optimization to improve the application's performance?

options.option_text: Rewrite the application using a faster programming language.
Implement an in-memory caching system to reduce redundant disk reads andwrites.
Increase the image resolution to improve processing accuracy.
Add more logging to monitor each step of the image processing pipeline.

questions.question_text_1:
You are developing a wireless communication module for an embedded system that transmits sensitive sensor data over a network. During testing, you discover that unauthorized devices can intercept the transmitted data. 
What is the most effective solution to protect the data from being accessed by unauthorized parties?
question_texts:
You are developing a wireless communication module for an embedded system that transmits sensitive sensor data over a network. During testing, you discover that unauthorized devices can intercept the transmitted data. 
What is the most effective solution to protect the data from being accessed by unauthorized parties?

options.option_text: Use encryption to secure the transmitted data.
Increase the transmission power to make the signal stronger.
Disable error-checking mechanisms to speed up communication.
Use a faster microcontroller to improve processing speed.

questions.question_text_1: You are designing an embedded system for an industrial monitoring device that must run continuously without failure. During testing, you observe that sometimes the system becomes unresponsive due to unexpected software bugs. which of the following can help the system recover if unexpected failures occur
question_texts: You are designing an embedded system for an industrial monitoring device that must run continuously without failure. During testing, you observe that sometimes the system becomes unresponsive due to unexpected software bugs. which of the following can help the system recover if unexpected failures occur

options.option_text: Implement a Watchdog Timer (WDT) to reset the system if it becomesunresponsive.
Use a faster microcontroller to prevent the system from hanging.
Disable interrupts to avoid unexpected behavior.
Increase the system clock speed to improve performance.

questions.question_text_1: You are developing a smart door lock system that operates on batteries and needs to remain functional for over a year without frequent recharging. Which processing unit should you choose for optimal performance and power efficiency?
question_texts: You are developing a smart door lock system that operates on batteries and needs to remain functional for over a year without frequent recharging. Which processing unit should you choose for optimal performance and power efficiency?

options.option_text: A microprocessor (MPU) to handle complex computing tasks efficiently
A microcontroller (MCU) to ensure low power consumption and long batterylife
A high-performance CPU to improve response time
A GPU to enhance graphical display processing on the lock

questions.question_text_1: A memory-mapped I/O device has a control register bank starting at address 0x20002000. Each register is 32 bits (4 bytes) wide. If there are 16 registers in the bank, what is the address of the 10th register?
question_texts: A memory-mapped I/O device has a control register bank starting at address 0x20002000. Each register is 32 bits (4 bytes) wide. If there are 16 registers in the bank, what is the address of the 10th register?

questions.question_text_1: A 12-bit ADC can digitize an analog value into ___ distinct levels.
question_texts: A 12-bit ADC can digitize an analog value into ___ distinct levels.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **Embedded C Programming** exam, along with a **Mermaid knowledge graph** to visualize relationships.

---

### **Core Topics & Key Concepts**
#### **1. Real-Time Operating Systems (RTOS)**
   - **Tasks & Scheduling**:
     - `xTaskCreate()`, `vTaskDelay()`, `vTaskDelete()`.
     - Task states: Running, Ready, Blocked, Suspended.
   - **Queues**:
     - `xQueueCreate()`, `xQueueSend()`, `xQueueReceive()`.
     - Behavior when queue is full (blocking sender).
   - **Priority Inversion**:
     - High-priority task blocked by low-priority task holding a shared resource.
   - **Timers**:
     - Enable periodic task execution without busy-waiting.
   - **Interrupts vs. Polling**:
     - Use interrupts for **asynchronous events** (e.g., button press).
     - Use polling for **periodic checks** (e.g., sensor readings).

#### **2. Finite State Machines (FSM)**
   - **States & Transitions**:
     - Example: Motor control (STOP → SLOW → FAST → OVERSPEED).
   - **Event Handling**:
     - `switch-case` logic for state transitions.
   - **Context Saving in ISRs**:
     - Save/restore registers to resume main program correctly.

#### **3. Memory Management**
   - **Static vs. Dynamic Allocation**:
     - Prefer **stack-based** or **static allocation** in embedded systems.
     - Avoid heap fragmentation (minimize `malloc/free`).
   - **Data Types for Optimization**:
     - Use `uint8_t` for values **0–100** (saves memory vs. `int`).
   - **Memory-Mapped I/O**:
     - Register addressing (e.g., `0x20002000 + (n * 4)` for 32-bit registers).

#### **4. Communication Protocols**
   - **I2C**:
     - 2-wire (SDA, SCL), supports **multiple devices** (no separate Chip Select).
   - **SPI**:
     - Faster, full-duplex, but requires **Chip Select per device**.
   - **I2S**:
     - Used for **audio playback** (DMA recommended for smooth transfer).

#### **5. Assembly & Low-Level Programming**
   - **Register Operations**:
     - `MOV`, `ADD`, `SUB` (e.g., `AX = 60 + 95 = 155`).
   - **Bitwise Shifts**:
     - `>> 3` divides by 8 (e.g., `0xD0 >> 3 = 0x1A`).

#### **6. Power & Performance Optimization**
   - **Low-Power Design**:
     - Use **microcontrollers (MCUs)** for battery-powered devices.
   - **DMA (Direct Memory Access)**:
     - Offloads CPU for **high-speed data transfers** (e.g., audio playback).
   - **Watchdog Timer (WDT)**:
     - Resets system on **hang/failure** (critical for industrial systems).

#### **7. Testing & Debugging**
   - **Unit Testing**:
     - Test **individual functions** in isolation (e.g., FSM state transitions).
   - **Profiling**:
     - Identify bottlenecks (e.g., disk I/O in image processing).
   - **Encryption**:
     - Secure **wireless sensor data** (e.g., AES for confidentiality).

#### **8. Hardware-Specific Concepts**
   - **ADC Resolution**:
     - 12-bit ADC → **4096 distinct levels** (2¹²).
   - **SRAM Addressing**:
     - Last byte of 256KB SRAM at `0x00400000`: `0x00400000 + 262143 = 0x0043FFFF`.

---

### **Key Equations & Calculations**
| **Topic**               | **Equation/Concept**                          | **Example**                          |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------|
| **Queue Blocking**      | If queue full, `xQueueSend()` blocks sender.  | `pdMS_TO_TICKS(1000)` timeout.       |
| **Memory Addressing**   | `Last Address = Base + Size - 1`              | `0x00400000 + 256KB - 1 = 0x0043FFFF`|
| **ADC Levels**          | `Levels = 2^n` (n = bits)                     | 12-bit → 4096 levels.                |
| **Bitwise Shift**       | `value >> n` ≡ `value / 2^n`                  | `0xD0 >> 3 = 0x1A` (208 / 8 = 26).   |
| **Register Offset**     | `Address = Base + (n * width)`               | 10th 32-bit reg: `0x20002000 + 36`.  |

---

### **Mermaid Knowledge Graph**
```mermaid
graph TD
    %% RTOS Core
    RTOS[RTOS] --> Tasks[Tasks & Scheduling]
    RTOS --> Queues[Queues]
    RTOS --> PriorityInversion[Priority Inversion]
    RTOS --> Timers[Timers]

    %% FSM & State Management
    FSM[Finite State Machine] --> States[States: STOP/SLOW/FAST]
    FSM --> Events[Events: Button Press/Sensor Alert]
    FSM --> ContextSaving[Context Saving in ISRs]

    %% Memory
    Memory[Memory Management] --> StaticAllocation[Static Allocation]
    Memory --> DataTypes[Optimized Data Types: uint8_t]
    Memory --> MMIO[Memory-Mapped I/O]

    %% Communication
    Comm[Communication Protocols] --> I2C[I2C: Multi-Device]
    Comm --> SPI[SPI: Fast, Full-Duplex]
    Comm --> I2S[I2S: Audio Playback]

    %% Low-Level
    LowLevel[Low-Level Programming] --> Assembly[Assembly: MOV/ADD]
    LowLevel --> BitwiseOps[Bitwise Shifts]

    %% Optimization
    Optimization[Power & Performance] --> DMA[DMA for Audio]
    Optimization --> WDT[Watchdog Timer]
    Optimization --> Encryption[Encryption for Security]

    %% Testing
    Testing[Testing & Debugging] --> UnitTesting[Unit Testing]
    Testing --> Profiling[Profiling Bottlenecks]

    %% Hardware
    Hardware[Hardware Concepts] --> ADC[ADC Resolution: 2^n]
    Hardware --> SRAM[SRAM Addressing]
```

```mermaid
graph TD
    %% Relationships Between Topics
    EmbeddedSystem[Embedded System] --> RTOS
    EmbeddedSystem --> FSM
    EmbeddedSystem --> Memory
    EmbeddedSystem --> Comm
    EmbeddedSystem --> LowLevel
    EmbeddedSystem --> Optimization
    EmbeddedSystem --> Testing
    EmbeddedSystem --> Hardware

    %% Example Workflow
    MotorControl[Motor Control System] --> FSM
    MotorControl --> RTOS
    AudioPlayer[Audio Player] --> I2S
    AudioPlayer --> DMA
    SensorNetwork[Sensor Network] --> I2C
    SensorNetwork --> Encryption
```

---

### **Exam Preparation Tips**
1. **Focus Areas**:
   - **RTOS**: Task/queue behavior, priority inversion, timers.
   - **FSM**: State transitions and event handling.
   - **Memory**: Static allocation, data type selection, MMIO.
   - **Protocols**: I2C vs. SPI vs. I2S use cases.
   - **Optimization**: DMA, WDT, low-power design.

2. **Practice**:
   - Write **FreeRTOS code snippets** (e.g., queues, tasks).
   - Design **FSM diagrams** for state transitions.
   - Calculate **memory addresses** and **ADC levels**.
   - Debug **assembly operations** (register values).

3. **Common Pitfalls**:
   - Assuming queues **auto-clear** (they block instead).
   - Using **dynamic memory** in embedded systems (risk of fragmentation).
   - Ignoring **context saving** in ISRs (crashes main program).
   - Choosing **SPI over I2C** for multi-device setups (extra Chip Select lines).
